newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks end softer as rebound fails.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks end softer as rebound fails.

text.p: Taiwan share prices ended slightly lower on Tuesday for the third straight session as an early rebound failed ahead of the seven-day Chinese new year holiday starting on February 4, brokers said.

The index ended down 10.75 points or 0.15 percent at 7,146.21, off a mid-session high of 7,182.64. Turnover was comparatively slow at T$50.4 billion, compared with over T$100 billion in recent sessions.
The index had opened higher, boosted partly by Monday's news that the island's leading business indicators had risen for a fourth consecutive month in December.
"Caution emerged since the rising leading indicators were supported mainly by the loose monetary policy, not by the manufacturing side," said HSBC James Capel analyst Alex Chen.

Investors were concerned whether the central bank's loose money policy would change in the near term, brokers said, although the bank reiterated on Monday that it would maintain its stable-to-loose policy to help foster economic recovery.

Brokers said they did not expect any monetary policy shift in the near term. "The loose money policy is needed in order to realise an economic recovery as well as for the government's state-share selling plan," Chen said.
The government recently said it planned to release more than T$100 billion in state shares in fiscal 1997/98 (July/June) to alleviate financial deficits, but wants to sell at high levels.
"The state-share selling plan is only possible when the stock market is doing well, and that's why the government has been so bullish toward the market recently," Chen said.
Electronics and financials fell. Plastics rose on producer price rises, with Union Petrochemical up 60 cents to T$38.70.
Brokers said they did not foresee major selling ahead of the lunar new year as most investors expect the government to make further bullish moves when post-holiday trading resumes.
A 7,100-7,200 trading range was seen for Wednesday.
